meanings.def: the act of firing a gun; the sound this makes
examples: We heard some shots in the distance.
shot at somebody/something Someone took a shot at the car.
shot to something She was killed by a single shot to the head.
The man fired several shots from his pistol.
I heard a pistol shot.
The shot hit him in the chest.

meanings.def: a person who shoots a gun in a particular way (well, badly, etc.)
examples: She is a crack shot with a rifle.

meanings.def: an attempt to score a goal or point in a game
examples: He took a shot from the edge of the box.
Taylor scored with a low shot into the corner of the net.
She turned and hit a shot that looked like a certain goal.
A defender managed to block his shot.
shot at something Unfortunately her shot at goal missed.
shot on something England had a few shots on goal.
He scuffed a shot from the edge of the box.
I took a few more shots at the target, but missed every time.
My first shot went wide, but my second was right on target.
The goalkeeper parried his first shot but he scored from the rebound.
Their captain tried a long shot on goal.
his right-footed shot from outside the penalty area

meanings.def: an act of hitting the ball
examples: Good shot!
Go on—take another shot.
She started the day one shot off the lead.

meanings.def: the heavy ball that is used in the sports competition called shot-put
a photograph
examples: We stood there patiently while he snapped a few shots.
I got some good shots of people at the party.
I decided to stop and take a quick shot of the street.
a photograph of the house
Can I take a photograph?
We had our picture taken in front of the hotel.
a passport photo
I tried to get a shot of him in the water.
holiday snaps
a set of prints
I tried to get a shot of him in the water.
publicity shots
She took a wide-angle shot of the house and garden.
Kate snapped a few shots with her camera through the window.
I got some great shots of the runners as they crossed the line.

meanings.def: a scene in a film that is filmed continuously by one camera
examples: the opening shot of a character walking across a desert
The director is clearly fond of tracking and aerial shots.
The exterior shots were filmed in Morocco and Malta.

meanings.def: a large number of small metal balls that you fire together from a shotgun
examples: Round shot whistled over our heads.
Conservationists have called on the government to ban the use of lead shot in shotgun cartridges.

meanings.def: a large stone or metal ball that was shot from a cannon or large gun in the past
a remark or an action that is usually one of a series, and is aimed against somebody/something that you are arguing or competing with
examples: This statement was the opening shot in the argument.
The supermarket fired the first shot in a price war today.
He couldn't resist taking a cheap shot at his political opponent.
As her parting shot she warned Pete never to come near her again.
the opening shot in the election campaign

meanings.def: the act of trying to do or achieve something
examples: The team are looking good for a shot at the title.
I've never produced a play before but I'll have a shot at it.
I'm willing to give it a shot.
Just give it your best shot (= try as hard as you can) and you'll be fine.

meanings.def: a small amount of a drug that is put into your body using a syringe
examples: a flu shot (= to protect you against flu)
a shot of morphine
Have you had all your shots for your expedition yet?
The applause acted on her like a shot of adrenalin.
a shot of penicillin

meanings.def: a small amount of a drink, especially a strong alcoholic one
examples: a shot of whisky

meanings.def: the process of sending a spacecraft into and through space
examples: The space shot was shown live on television.
a moon shot

meanings.def: a horse, dog, etc. that has the particular chance of winning a race that is mentioned
examples: The horse is a 10–1 shot.

meanings.def: an important person
to be the person who controls a situation
very quickly and without hesitating
examples: If I had the chance to go there, I'd go like a shot.

meanings.def: an attempt or a guess that is not likely to be successful but is worth trying
examples: It's a long shot, but it just might work.

meanings.def: not nearly; not at all
examples: It's not over yet—not by a long shot.

meanings.def: a final remark, especially an unkind one, that somebody makes as they leave
examples: As her parting shot she warned Pete never to come near her again.

meanings.def: something that you say or do as a warning to somebody about what might happen if they do not change, etc.
something that encourages somebody/something or gives them the help they need
examples: Their enthusiasm has been a shot in the arm for all of us.

meanings.def: a guess; something you do without knowing what the result will be
examples: The figure he came up with was really just a shot in the dark.
It was only a stab in the dark, but I hoped I could learn something.
